title: Chapter 3: Encapsulation - Quiz
description: Comprehensive test of data hiding, private/protected attributes, properties, getters/setters, and name mangling

questions.question: What is encapsulation in OOP?
questions.explanation: Encapsulation bundles data and methods that operate on data within a single unit.

questions.question: What does a single underscore prefix indicate?
questions.explanation: Single underscore (_var) is a convention indicating protected/internal use.

questions.question: What does double underscore prefix do?
questions.explanation: Double underscore (__var) triggers name mangling to _ClassName__var.

questions.question: What is data hiding?
questions.explanation: Data hiding restricts direct access to internal state, providing access through methods.

questions.question: What is a getter method?
questions.explanation: A getter retrieves/returns the value of a private attribute.

questions.question: What is a setter method?
questions.explanation: A setter sets/modifies the value of a private attribute with validation.

questions.question: How do you create a property getter in Python?
questions.explanation: Use @property decorator to create a getter that's accessed like an attribute.

questions.question: How do you create a property setter?
questions.explanation: Use @property_name.setter decorator to create a setter for a property.

questions.question: What is name mangling?

options.text: Python's way of making attributes harder to access

questions.explanation: Name mangling transforms __var to _ClassName__var to avoid name conflicts.

questions.question: Can you still access name-mangled attributes?
questions.explanation: Name-mangled attributes can still be accessed using _ClassName__attribute syntax.

questions.question: What is the purpose of encapsulation?

options.text: Control access and protect data integrity

questions.explanation: Encapsulation controls access to data and maintains integrity through validation.

questions.question: What's the convention for public attributes?
questions.explanation: Public attributes have no underscore prefix, indicating they're part of the public API.

questions.question: What is the benefit of using properties?
questions.explanation: Properties allow validation and controlled access while maintaining simple attribute syntax.

questions.question:
What happens if you access __private outside class?
```python
class Test:
    def __init__(self):
        self.__private = 10

t = Test()
print(t.__private)
```
questions.explanation: Direct access to __private raises AttributeError due to name mangling.
Access mangled attributes using _ClassName__attribute format.

questions.question: What is a read-only property?
questions.explanation: Read-only property has @property getter but no setter, preventing modification.

questions.question: Why use getters/setters over direct access?
questions.explanation: Getters/setters enable validation, computed values, and maintain encapsulation.

questions.question: What does @property replace?
questions.explanation: @property allows method calls to look like attribute access: obj.name instead of obj.get_name().

questions.question: Can properties have deleters?

options.text: Yes, but only for class variables

questions.explanation: Properties can have deleters using @property_name.deleter decorator.

questions.question: What's the Pythonic approach to encapsulation?
questions.explanation: Python trusts developers - we're all consenting adults. Use conventions like _ prefix.

questions.question: Python has true private attributes like Java.
questions.explanation: Python uses conventions and name mangling, but attributes are still technically accessible.

questions.question: Single underscore _var is a convention, not enforced.
questions.explanation: Single underscore is purely conventional - Python doesn't enforce it.

questions.question: Double underscore triggers name mangling.
questions.explanation: Double underscore (__var) causes Python to mangle the name to _ClassName__var.

questions.question: Properties allow attribute-like access to methods.
questions.explanation: @property decorator makes methods accessible like attributes.

questions.question: Getters and setters are required for all attributes.
questions.explanation: Only use getters/setters when you need validation or computed values.

questions.question: Name mangling prevents all external access.
questions.explanation: Name mangling doesn't prevent access - it just makes it harder using _ClassName__var.

questions.question: Encapsulation improves code maintainability.
questions.explanation: Encapsulation protects internal state and makes code easier to maintain.

questions.question: Properties can have validation logic.
questions.explanation: Property setters commonly include validation to protect data integrity.

questions.question: You must define setter to have read-write property.
questions.explanation: Without a setter, property is read-only; setter enables write access.

questions.question: Protected attributes use double underscore.
questions.explanation: Protected uses single underscore (_); double underscore (__) is for name mangling.

questions.question: Which indicate access levels? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Python uses no prefix (public), _ (protected), __ (name mangling). ___ isn't a convention.

questions.question: Benefits of encapsulation? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Encapsulation provides validation, controlled access, and data integrity - not necessarily speed.

questions.question: Property decorators? (Select all)
questions.explanation: @property is the getter; @name.setter and @name.deleter follow. No @name.getter.

questions.question: When to use properties? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Use properties when needed for validation, computation, or control - not universally.

questions.question: Name mangling prevents? (Select all)
questions.explanation: Name mangling prevents accidents and conflicts, but not all access.

questions.question: Complete: Protected attribute
questions.explanation: Single underscore indicates protected attribute by convention.

questions.question: Complete: Private attribute with name mangling
questions.explanation: Double underscore triggers name mangling for private attributes.

questions.question: Complete: Property getter
questions.explanation: @property decorator creates a getter method.

questions.question: Complete: Property setter
questions.explanation: Use @property_name.setter to create setter for property.

questions.question: Complete: Access mangled attribute
questions.explanation: Access mangled attributes using _ClassName__attribute.

questions.question: Implement Getter and Setter
questions.description: Create BankAccount class with private __balance. Add getter and setter using @property.

questions.question: Protected Attribute Convention
questions.description: Create Employee class with protected _salary and public method get_salary() that returns it.

questions.question: Read-Only Property
questions.description: Create Circle class with private __radius. Add read-only property 'area' that computes π*r².

questions.question: Validation in Setter
questions.description: Create Person class with age property. Setter must validate age is between 0 and 150.

questions.question: Name Mangling
questions.description: Create class with __secret attribute. Add method to access it internally.

parts.question: What is encapsulation?
parts.explanation: Encapsulation bundles data and methods in a single unit.

parts.question: Encapsulation protects data integrity
parts.explanation: Encapsulation controls access and validates data.

parts.question: Benefits? (Select all)
parts.explanation: Encapsulation provides hiding, validation, control - not speed.

parts.question: Public attribute convention?
parts.explanation: Public attributes have no underscore prefix.

parts.question: Properties allow validation
parts.explanation: Setters can validate before setting values.

parts.question: Getters retrieve attribute values
parts.explanation: Getters return the value of attributes.

parts.question: Why use properties?
parts.explanation: Properties provide validation and controlled access.
